results.title: Thomson of Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Michael Cummins, John Moore, Michael McMahon, John Moore Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In the 1930s tensions between the government and the indigenous people of Australia’s North were on a knife-edge. Donald Thomson, an anthropologist, volunteered to go to Arnhem Land to make peace. For over two years, he lived with the Aboriginal people, forging strong bonds, learning and recording their way of life. His report to the government outlined a vision of land rights and other measures to protect a unique yet fragile culture. It was ignored. Ostracised by politicians and fellow academics, Thomson never gave up the struggle for Aboriginal rights. Now, his extraordinary photographs, field notes and artefacts are considered one of the most significant ethnographic collections in the world. Thomson’s collection is held at the Museum of Victoria in Melbourne. Narrated by Anni Finsterer. Music by David Bridie.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Cummins, John Moore, Michael McMahon, John Moore Productions and Film Australia

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Stuart Glover, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy
results.brief_description: Story of immigration and discussion of how newcomers look for houses, units or commission housing on offer in the city. Immigration officers help migrants get loans and settle in ‘suburbia’, the ideal for many migrants.

results.title: Sunbury
results.creator_credit: John Dixon and Cambridge Film Production
results.brief_description: The Sunbury Music Festival, held each Australia Day between 1972 and 1975 holds fond memories for the 35,000 plus people who attended. This video shows highlights of the first festival in 1972 and captures the excitement of a festival which showcased Australian Rock music and provides a document of Australian society in the seventies.

results.title: The Woman Suffers
results.creator_credit: Raymond Longford and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This 1918 Australian feature is one of the most significant surviving treasures of a silent film heritage which is now largely extinct. The story takes the concept of primitive justice - an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth - and extends it to a sister for a sister. Ralph Manton discovers that his sister Marjory has been seduced and demands to be told the name of the man. Faithful to her lover, she refuses, but later Ralph discovers his identity and confronts him. The tables are turned. Starring Australia’s first film star, Lottie Lyell, the film was a critical and commercial success and offered audiences more than just a melodrama. It questioned the social mores of the day and the double standards of morality in regard to the men as the seducers. Musical accompaniment is by members of the Canberra Symphony Orchestra, conducted by composer Donald Hollier.

results.title: Graeme Bell
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Often described as the ‘father of Australian jazz’ Graeme Bell has had a sixty year love affair with music, both as a performer and a composer. Discover the story of his life, speak to the man about his passion, and hear his wonderful music.

results.title: Mabo: The Life of an Island Man
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Denise Haslem and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Trevor Graham documented the only film record of the Mabo proceedings in 1989 in his film “Land Bilong islanders” and in the process established a friendship with Eddie Koiki Mabo. This film documents the extraordinary life of a man so passionate about his family and home that he fought an entire nation and its legal system. Sadly, he died five months before the High Court upheld his claim for “Native Title”. However he cemented a place in Australia’s history. This documentary won an AFI award in 1997.

results.title: Telephone technique
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Wesley Greene and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: Part of a series on sales training, this episode deals with telephone training for retail sales clerks. It emphasizes good telephone manners, wide knowledge of stock, importance of correct customer name and address and the necessity for an intelligent descriptive vocabulary when speaking of merchandise over the telephone.

results.title: The Getting of Wisdom
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams, Australian Film Commission and Southern Cross Film Productions
results.brief_description: Laura Tweedle Ramsbotham is about to enter another world. From her home in sleepy, rural Australia she ascends to the dreaming spires of an exclusive college for young ladies, a very strict Victorian boarding school in Melbourne. Laura (Susannah Fowles) is strong willed and rebellious, which creates conflict with her peers and her teachers. In a desperate attempt to find acceptance with her peers, she weaves the most lurid yarns imaginable. The only real soulmate she finds is one of the senior girls. The novel by Henry Handel Richardson was published in 1910, and was so shocking at the time that the author’s name (Ethel Richardson) was stricken from the records of the school in which she set the thinly-disguised autobiography. An amusing and sometimes touching story which features an excellent performance from Barry Humphries as the repressed fire and brimstone minister. Also stars John Waters, Sheila Helpman, Patricia Kennedy and Julie Blake.

results.title: Don's Party
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams and Art House Productions
results.brief_description: Bruce Beresford’s classic Australian comedy exposes Australian social mores in the suburbs. Don and Kath have invited a group of friends to celebrate what they believe will be a Labor Party victory on Election night. The night begins happily enough until the guests receive the news that Labor is losing. Old enmities erupt as hostilities break out amongst the guests as the party disintegrates into an alcoholic disaster. Cast includes Ray Barrett, Graham Kennedy, John Hargreaves, Graeme Blundell, Jeanie Drynan and Clare Binney.
